body: To keep that New Year's celebration on the light side, consider sprightly and subtly sparkling pear cider from Ireland. It's delicately sweetened, delivers only 4.5 percent alcohol and behaves properly in a flute for toasting. Magners has been known for its more traditional apple cider for 75 years. Magners Pear Cider is $7.99 for a four-pack of
title: FOOD STUFF; A Gentler Start To the New Year

body: Preston Chaney is a man of few words. If he were given to boasting, he might reveal that he is the first person in his family to graduate from high school, and will be the first to attend college. But things could have easily turned out differently. He was a sophomore at Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn when he dropped out in 2008. ''I was
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Looking Forward to a Dorm Room to Call His Own

body: SALUTING the new year huddled around the hearth with family and friends -- bedecked in sequins and plastic ''2011'' spectacles, spilling warm Champagne on the sofa -- is good, old-fashioned fun. But wouldn't you rather spend the night with Patti Smith? Whether you're bidding 2010 a hearty, don't-let-the-door-hit-you-on-the-way-out farewell or
title: Beyond Popping Corks, The Sounds of the New Year

body: He reached for her hand. It had been five weeks since the accident. Emilie Gossiaux, 21, lay in a bed in the surgical intensive-care unit at Bellevue Hospital Center. She could not see. She could not hear. Beyond asking for water, she spoke very little. Her boyfriend, Alan Lundgard, 21, took her left palm in his. Ms. Gossiaux was riding her bicycle
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; Hit by a Truck and Given Up For Dead, a Woman Fights Back

body: Metropolitan New York is being rapidly reshaped as blacks, Latinos, Asians and immigrants surge into the suburbs, while gentrification by whites is widening the income gap in neighborhoods in Manhattan and Brooklyn, according to new census figures released on Tuesday. Some of the largest population gains since 2000 were recorded in places that not
title: In New York, Black and Hispanic Strongholds Become More White

body: DAVID PABANA was standing on a sidewalk one day this fall when a baseball some children had been playing with rolled into the fence behind him. He threw the ball back to the children. It was at once the most routine act of neighborliness and one of the strangest journeys a baseball can make in New York City. When the ball left Mr. Pabana's hand, it
title: Of Kings And Queens

body: Several notable features of Flatbush Gardens, a 59-building rental complex in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, are missing from its inviting ads, which show comely young couples enjoying life there. Among the site's woes: dried feces and toilet paper carpet some basements, unleashing an unholy stink; one of its owners, David Bistricer, is on the New York
title: Violations and Lockout Mire Brooklyn Complex

title: Mixing Drinks, Adding Class

Tucking one boy under each arm, he hightailed it every morning across the street in Bushwick to a
title: As City Fixes Buildings, and Plans for More, Repayments Lag

body: Nineteen years ago, Peter Robyn's 10-year-old son came home from school on a day that, for Mr. Robyn, will live in infamy. It was Dec. 7, 1991, the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor, and Mr. Robyn asked his son if he had learned about the event in class. He was surprised when his son said no. ''My father served in World War II, and it
title: Drawing The Lessons Of History, Poster-Size

body: When Jessica Torres is nervous, words flutter from her mouth like butterflies in springtime, flitting in every direction. As she giggles, short phrases fly from her lips, colliding with each other, trailing off or suddenly reappearing. ''It makes me feel like ...,'' she begins. And ''honestly, you know, like ...,'' she begins again, a split second
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; MetroCard Blazes Mother's Path to a Job

body: There is no way that Flor Lazo could have memories of the unspeakable crime that rocked her homeland, El Salvador, on a distant Dec. 2. That monstrous deed -- the torture, rape and murder of four American churchwomen by a military death squad -- took place in 1980, a brutal time in El Salvador. Ms. Lazo was not born until five years later. Yet she
title: NYC; After 30 Years, Preserving Nuns' Legacy

body: Normal Bob grew up in normal little towns in the Midwest. But after visiting Union Square Park, where normalcy is recognized more in the breach than the observance, he decided to move to New York in 2002. Since then, Normal Bob has become a daily fixture in the park. He is relatively unremarkable by downtown Manhattan standards -- cuffed jeans, Doc
title: Chronicling Oddness In Union Square Park

body: Words flowed from Raheem Watson in a stream, thick with assurance, buttressed by years of quiet introspection. But one question gave him pause, forcing his gaze down to his lap. Did he have a choice? ''Wow,'' he said. Seconds passed, the first quiet moments of the night. He had two decades of strife to ponder. Mr. Watson, 26, was born in
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; After Years Caught Up in Violence, a Second Chance to Reflect on Fate

body: DEAR DIARY: Serving in the Army during the Vietnam War in the late 1960s, I spent a year in Washington learning Laotian. Since the United States was not officially in Laos at the time, I was sent to a linguist holding company at Fort Hood in Texas for the remaining two years of my enlistment, ready to ship out should the need arise. Fortunately, my
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: WHOEVER said New York night life is dead hasn't been out recently. Despite the economic gloom, or maybe because of it, a crush of late-night parties, luscious lounges and chest-thumping clubs are opening across the city. The meatpacking district is a tangle of new velvet ropes. D.J.'s are trekking to the nether reaches of Bushwick. The Lower East
title: The New Club Kids

body: Last June, Zaida Paris-Mendez was at the beauty salon when a neighbor called to tell her that people were moving things out of her apartment. She knew immediately that the landlord was trying to evict her, her husband and their two children from their $700-a-month rent-controlled apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It had happened before. In a
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; After a Landlord Dispute and a Layoff, Finding a New Home

body: Lean, tattooed and hunky in the way of a young Henry Rollins, Brian Reaume is living the life of a gay indie Brooklyn or Bay Area artist. He lives in what real estate agents call a ''transitional'' neighborhood, in a house filled with midcentury furniture and quirky art by him and his friends. In a small shop on a funky strip of cafes, bars and
title: TALK; Hello, Columbus

title: The Big Squeeze

body: On Thursday morning, Luis Crossman, 61, slipped his still-lean, 61-year-old body into a faded green jumpsuit and zipped it up. He pulled on his black army boots and put on his aviator shades and black cowboy hat. He tied a kerchief around his neck. ''Happy Veterans Day,'' he said, giving a tight salute, stiffening his spine and snapping together
title: Spirit of Camaraderie Persists at a Shelter for Veterans

body: Experiences along the New York City Marathon's 26.2-mile route were as diverse as the 45,350 official entrants who ran it Sunday. For some, the morning of the marathon was a time of uncertainty. Erwin Franieck rode the downtown R train in Brooklyn at 8:30 a.m. in sneakers and shorts -- out of place among the parkas and scarves in the car. Franieck,
title: Along the Route, a Variety Of Music and Messages

body: ON the surface Jonah Bokaer is nearly ethereal, with brown eyes that melt and a tendency to speak in near-whispers. But when he laughs -- hearty and devilish -- a more tangible side shines through: it's as if Mr. Bokaer, 29, is an old man stuck in a young person's body. His apparent meekness isn't timidity but armor. Mr. Bokaer's accomplishments
title: Stretch Work: From Young To Old(er)

body: After New York State passed a law this summer extending residential rights to people living in illegal lofts in much of the city, the seven tenants of 360 Jefferson Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, acted fast. Theirs was not a pretty building: two and a half stories of dung-colored bricks punctuated by windows encased in rusting metal mesh, on a
title: Seeking a New Law's Protection, Loft Tenants Instead Find Grief

body: Anyone who has been lost in the last few weeks around the southern reaches of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn could be excused for experiencing a powerful Koch administration flashback. title: Now Everyone Can Read the Writing on the Wall

body: Larger-than-life characters, titanic egos, brazen deceit, bloody combat: with such things is Wagner's grandiose four-opera cycle, ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' concerned. That those characteristics are hardly specific to the Norse mythology of Wagner's scenario, however, has endowed this lofty 19th-century creation with enduring resonance. Clever
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'THE RING CYCLE (PART 1 + 2)'; Spears and Spandex: Wagner via World Wide Wrestling

body: LIKE many liberal-minded New Yorkers, I find racial profiling abhorrent. But there is one place that I, like many liberal-minded New Yorkers, profile people all the time, and not only by race but also by age, ethnicity and sartorial choices: on the subway. I'm a 27-year-old Hebrew school teacher and freelance writer who crisscrosses the city
title: NEW YORK STORY; Profiling for a Seat

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Indie Scene's Uncomplicated Side

title: A Commune Grows in Brooklyn

title: DANCE REVIEW; Secrets of Perception In a Brooklyn Aerie

title: Where the Sidewalks End, And the City (Really) Begins

body: The blackboard at Public School 212 in the Bronx made the sole objective for the first day of school plainly clear: defining rules and routines. No gum. No tardiness. No talking. No getting out of your seat. ''Every moment in this class matters,'' Harris Sockel told his seventh-grade language arts class, with a mix of encouragement and
title: Back in Class, the Theme Is: We Will Succeed With Less

body: TWENTY years ago, when Fifth Avenue in Park Slope could still be called marginal in the pages of The New York Times, Michael Ayoub opened Cucina there, on the corner of Carroll Street. The restaurant was an elegantly casual Italian trattoria that managed to charm both a burgeoning population of young brownstoners with jobs in Manhattan and the
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; Who Needs the Gastrotourists?

body: Perched high above an industrial stretch of East Williamsburg, a menacing robot nine feet high and seven feet wide surveys the street below, watching cars steal past graffitied factory buildings as if they were prey. Its fierce head sways and dips when a wooden rudder protruding from the back of its neck catches the breeze. This is the Brooklyn
title: CITY ROOM; Above a Hummus Restaurant, a Makeshift Robot Finds a Home

body: Marooned on a lonesome block, at the corner of 21st Street and 49th Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, the M. Wells diner serves a Québécois take on short-order cooking: from crab and egg hash to pickled pork tongue. Opened this summer and offering, for the moment, breakfast and lunch but no dinner, it is housed in a restored chrome structure,
title: AT THE TABLE | M. WELLS; Going Québécois Before Going West

body: New York City schoolchildren are as heavy, or perhaps even heavier, than the national average, despite the Bloomberg administration's dogged efforts to improve the health of city residents, according to new data from the city's health department. Two out of five, or 40 percent, of the nearly 637,000 children in kindergarten through the eighth grade
title: City's Efforts Fail to Dent Child Obesity

body: NEW YORK'S pizza moment is stretching into a pizza era. The wood-burning ovens and rock-star pizzaioli that seemed exotic not long ago are becoming familiar. A blistered, bubbling 12-inch Naples-style pizza, once a hard-to-find pleasure, is almost routine. Three new pizzerias add to the abundance. They might not seem to have much in common, but
title: $25 AND UNDER; Make It the New York Neapolitan Area

''You rip it open,'' he said, demonstrating how to pinch the bottom of the tail to extract a bit of
title: Southern Seafood's Rolling Boil

title: In Brooklyn Store, Everything Is Always 100% Off

body: The view from 204 Forsyth Street has gone from dilapidated to deluxe. Five stories above the bustling streets of the Lower East Side, the Rev. Jack Podsiadlo leaned over the rooftop cornice of this narrow, red-brick tenement and counted all the boutiques and nightspots that have moved in. title: Lower East Side Has Less to Offer Jesuits Who Teach the Poor

body: THOUGH it resides in a prime example of traditional museum architecture -- a Beaux-Arts building designed in 1893 by McKim, Mead & White -- there is little stale or stodgy about the Brooklyn Museum. For more than a century the museum has been one of the country's most important cultural institutions, and for more than a decade it has also courted
title: Sketching A Future For Brooklyn Museum

body: A 30-year-old man who confessed to the 2008 baseball-bat murder of a 31-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant by saying, ''So I killed someone - that makes me a bad guy?'' was sentenced on Thursday to more than 30 years in prison. The defendant, Keith Phoenix, was convicted in May of attacking Jose O. Sucuzhanay on a street corner in Bushwick, Brooklyn,
title: CITY ROOM; 2 Men Sentenced in Beating Death of Ecuadorean Immigrant in Brooklyn

There were tricorn hats, vests and, in a few cases, shirts with long, flowing sleeves. Many of the bicycles were decorated with cardboard cutouts in the shape of a horse's head. One man rang a bell. title: 'The Bulldozers Are Coming': A Garden Crusade

body: If print is dead, the people who planned these events sure don't know it. title: Weekend Miser

body: Over the years, Michael Kronberg, a 46-year-old artist, grew to accept, if not always love, the quirks and pitfalls that came with living in his loft in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Among them: The 49-year-old practicing nudist who wandered the halls. The drug-dealing roommate whose frequent guests included addicts and a dominatrix who dabbled in black
title: That Cheap, Roomy, Sunny Loft Can Now Be a Legal One, Too

author: Rachel Aviv is a Rosalynn Carter fellow for mental-health journalism and a frequent contributor to Education Life.
body: HANNAH WOLFE traveled to school by air last year. It required precise timing, a skill she honed when she and her friends moved to what they called Rosy -- a sprawling apartment complex on Roosevelt Island that doubles as a dorm. All her classes at Marymount Manhattan College were on the Upper East Side, and to get there, she took two buses and a
title: EMPIRE STATE OF MIND; Backpacks Among the Briefcases

body: Austin, Tex., has the Alamo Drafthouse. San Francisco has Foreign Cinema. Portland, Ore., has McMenamins. And Brooklyn has -- well, Brooklyn has many places where you can bring a blanket and a picnic basket and watch a film in a park or on a rooftop, but few indoor options for dinner-and-a-movie year-round. title: Movie on the Screen, Dinner on the Plate, Hubcaps at the Bar

title: CITY ROOM; Nocturnalist; Who Says Too Many Cooks Spoil the Broth?

body: JUST over a year ago, Mark and Alejandra Ryan arrived in New York with little more than, as he put it, ''a healthy dose of naïveté.'' The couple chose New York for two reasons. title: THE HUNT; Room for the Dog to Wag His Tail

body: DEAR DIARY: I tutor a fifth grader at the Star Learning Center on the Upper West Side. At a recent session, my student told me that his class was going on a trip to Gettysburg, Pa., and he had an assignment to learn the Gettysburg Address. We spent the last part of our session working on this. My student's older brother was walking him home, and I
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: IN the parking lot behind Castle Braid, a new rental complex in Bushwick, Brooklyn, BMWs and Volvos sit beside murals by local graffiti legends like Jesus Saves and Robots Will Kill. The luxury cars are something of an anomaly in Bushwick, the working-class neighborhood to the east of Williamsburg that is New York's current locus of bohemianism.
title: POSTING; Starving Artists Need Not Apply

body: For years there wasn't much to see on this industrial block near the border of Bushwick and East Williamsburg. Welders sprayed iron sparks inside Metro Hi-Tech Steel and Builders, and garbage trucks dumped trash into the BFI Waste Systems warehouse. But lately, there are cloth-covered tables, fresh kiwis and avocados in baskets and vintage mopeds
title: BUSHWICK JOURNAL; Amid Warehouses, Gourmet Sandwiches, Yoga Classes and Yarn

body: A proclamation from Marty Markowitz, the excitable Brooklyn borough president, is no rarity. But receiving it under the head of a quasianimatronic wolf-creature, while, around the corner, a guy upholsters a seat cushion in brown argyle, and another blends cocktails by bike -- that is something special. At a party for its fourth anniversary last
title: Urban Artisans: A Collective Thrives in Brooklyn

title: The Listings

body: A SUMMER share in the five boroughs? A gay-themed circus? A subway to the next Jersey Shore? Forget about the Jitney. Summer offers plenty of reasons to stay in New York. Here are 10 new hot spots to drink, party, play and chill in the city. FOOD AND DRINK 1. Rooftop Bar With rooftop bars popping up across the city skyline with dizzying frequency
title: 10 New Hot Spots If Summer Needs Sizzle

body: BENEATH a floating dock off Governors Island, tucked behind the squat octagonal white ventilation tower for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, there are oysters growing in New York Harbor. And not just any oysters. These little bivalves, 500,000 strong, make up the largest concentrated oyster population that the harbor has seen in perhaps a century. On a
title: Nurturing New York's Oysters

body: The surfing dudes could load up on veggies and fruit at some Greenmarket before they jumped on the A Train to Rockaway Beach. But it's easier to do the shopping once they get there, at the new little market in the expanding, ramshackle complex anchored by Rockaway Taco. Elizabeth Gilchrist, a partner (shown with her dog, Baby), said the produce is
title: FOOD STUFF; Vegetable Stand Sprouts In Rockaway Beach

body: A 30-year-old man accused of beating an Ecuadorean immigrant to death on a Brooklyn street was convicted on Monday of murder as a hate crime. A jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn delivered the verdict around 9 p.m., after seven hours of deliberations. The decision came at the end of a two-week retrial of Keith Phoenix on charges stemming from
title: Man Guilty of Murder as Hate Crime

body: It turns out that the L train, that horizontal hotbed of hipsters, is also a popular place to fall in love. And then go write about it on the Internet. Several of the gray line's stops in Williamsburg and Bushwick, Brooklyn, have been ranked among the most romantic subway stations in the city, according to a recent study. Did psychologists scour
title: CITY ROOM; The L (for-Love) Train Goes to Williamsburg and Bushwick

body: Turns out the Gowanus Canal is socially as well as environmentally inhospitable. Just two weeks after announcing its intention to do a summer's worth of programming at the Bklyn Yard, an event space by the canal, Sunday Best, a weekly electronica party, will move on, its founders said. Though licensing for alcohol and other details were proceeding
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Bklyn Yard Party Now at a New Location

body: The empty glassine packets can be found in Manhattan, Brooklyn and beyond, scattered on streets and sidewalks with only obscure slogans or graphic images to suggest their former use. At one time they contained heroin and the markings stamped on the packets were meant to differentiate strains of varying purity or provenance. To some they are crime
title: The Art of the Potentially Deadly Deal: Marketing Heroin on the Street

body: By some standards, a developer's plan to transform the defunct Domino Sugar refinery north of the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn is a good deal, offering 660 of its planned 2,200 apartments to poor and working-class New Yorkers, shops to animate the streets and a public esplanade along the East River. ''We're taking this narrow, vacant industrial
title: 2 Sides Clash at City Hall Over Domino Housing Plan

body: In New York City, it is not just the colleges that can snag high-profile commencement speakers. High schools large and small are also celebrating their graduations with wit and wisdom from some major names. The best-known selective high schools, Stuyvesant and the Bronx High School of Science, each have about 800 graduates a year, helping them
title: CITY ROOM; High Schools in City Draw Big-Name Graduation Speakers

body: Nell Kathleen Clement, a daughter of Mickey Clement and John Clement of Huntington, N.Y., was married Saturday to Benjamin Aram Yurman-Glaser, a son of Beth Yurman and Arthur Glaser of Rochester. Nancy Yurman, an aunt of the bridegroom, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Martha Clara Vineyards in Riverhead, N.Y.
title: Nell Clement, Benjamin Yurman-Glaser

body: As beauty queens beamed and Latin dancers shimmied up Fifth Avenue, the Garcia, Gomez and Vazquez families reclaimed the spread of pavement that becomes their temporary home one day each year. Like thousands of other New Yorkers who regularly attend the National Puerto Rican Day Parade, members of this loose-knit clan of friends, relatives and
title: At the Parade, a Day of Traditions and Familiar Faces

body: Week to week. That's how the great state of New York is making do during these sorry days of fiscal ridiculousness. Since the state has seen fit to get along without an annual budget, an emergency spending bill gets approved every week authorizing just enough money to enable New York to squeeze through the next seven days. One of these weeks, well,
title: In These Difficult Times, New York State's Motto Could Be: Will Tattoo for Food

body: ''ELEVEN friends, two grills, one tiny Brooklyn backyard -- even the food was happy!'' Bruria Markovitz wrote. Indeed, who could resist those watermelon eyes? (See the top photo at right.) Ms. Markovitz is one of scores of people who have sent in photographs of their backyard barbecues as part of Metropolitan's summerlong project ''Around the
title: What's Around Your Grill?

body: IT was Friday night, and the face paint was optional, but few people abstained. Why? Because here was a woman in pasties and a giant pink beehive talking to a guy in a unitard with a balloon for a head, who called himself the Eye of Disorient. There was a woman in a nude body stocking, with artfully applied glitter, go-go dancing on a platform. A
title: Social Disrobing And Other Party Fare

body: You don't have to be a baseball pitcher from Detroit throwing the game of your life to get robbed in the big city. Heck, you don't even have to play baseball to get robbed, cheated, wronged -- to have your own perfect little game called life on any particular day botched by that great and menacing and half-blind umpire that is New York. On
title: A Perfect Game? Too Bad. But in New York, Everybody Gets Robbed.

body: Prompted by a wide-ranging investigation into the cases of about 15 girls who said they were forced into prostitution, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn said Wednesday that he was creating a Sex Trafficking Unit to take aim at those who sexually exploit women and girls. Eight people have been indicted on charges that include sex
title: 8 Charged in Brooklyn In Sex-Trafficking Case

body: THOUGH I have been a vegan for a decade, I've always been fascinated by barbecuing (teriyaki-marinated tofu is delicious if you can keep it from sticking to the grill). Maybe it's because I grew up in the South, eating a home-cooked meal every night of my life -- often a slab of meat fired on the back porch -- and have long been intrigued by how
title: SUMMER RITUALS | AROUND THE GRILL; Cooking Out In the City, No Backyard Necessary

body: THERE are really only two problems with Prime Meats, the very good and very beautiful Germanish restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. The first is that the restaurant accepts no reservations, which can wreak havoc on the evening schedules of visitors who come from beyond walking distance to eat there. You can see these people standing on Court
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; Weisswurst Never Felt So Proud

body: A Manhattan judge has scheduled a hearing next month to determine whether the city's plan to develop public housing in a rundown patch of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, would essentially foster segregation. In a 22-page decision issued on Thursday, the judge, Emily Jane Goodman of State Supreme Court, indicated that there might be some merit in claims
title: Judge Agrees To Consider Bias Claims In Zoning Suit

body: EVEN preschool teachers unwind with a round of drinks now and then. But in professional kitchens, where the hours are long, the pace intense and the goal is to deliver pleasure, the need to blow off steam has long involved substances that are mind-altering and, often enough, illegal. ''Everybody smokes dope after work,'' said Anthony Bourdain, the
title: Creating A Cuisine Out of Smoke

body: The stretch of Northern Boulevard near 36th Street in Long Island City, Queens, is about as far from bucolic as it gets: Old industrial buildings loom, traffic whizzes by, car dealerships line the street. Off in the distance, Manhattan's skyscrapers glitter, the trains rumble, and the closest thing to a meadow is a small patch of plants the Parks
title: Six Stories Above Queens, a Fine Spot for a Little Farming

body: After more than three days of jury deliberations, a holdout juror prompted a mistrial Tuesday night in the hate crime trial of a Brooklyn man accused of beating an Ecuadorean immigrant to death. About 9 p.m. Tuesday, Justice Patricia M. DiMango of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn announced that the jury was hopelessly deadlocked in the case of Keith
title: Mistrial in Brooklyn Hate Crime Case

body: For decades, public health experts have tried -- and mostly failed -- to contain an asthma epidemic that afflicts many New Yorkers living in the city's poorest neighborhoods. But now, the City Council hopes to significantly curtail the spread of the lung disease by forcing landlords at some of the most badly maintained buildings to clean up their
title: Program to Combat Asthma Would Lean on Landlords

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: HITTING 30 was a turning point for Andy Lagrimas. He was more than ready to rent a place of his own. Before that, to afford Manhattan, he found it necessary to share an apartment. But ''I made a resolution when I turned 30 to say goodbye to roommates,'' said Mr. Lagrimas, who reached that milestone last fall. ''I felt too old to be doing the
title: THE HUNT; My Roommate? Me, Myself and I

body: The unfailing difference between old vegetable recipes and new ones is that cooking times have plunged. Old string-bean recipes routinely called for seven minutes of boiling. If you want limp, waterlogged beans -- and flashbacks to the third-grade lunchroom -- this is the way to get them. Today vegetables are cooked until, in the language of
title: RECIPE REDUX; Asparagus Alla Fontina, 1977

body: A Brooklyn man was convicted of manslaughter on Thursday for his role in the killing of an Ecuadorean immigrant, but he was acquitted of more serious hate-crime charges. After less than a day of deliberations, a jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court found the man, Hakim Scott, guilty of first-degree manslaughter in the death of José O. Sucuzhañay, who
title: Man Convicted of Killing Immigrant, but Not of Hate Crime

body: About an hour after a Brooklyn jury started deliberations in a hate crime murder trial, an alternate juror who was excused to take care of her child said Wednesday that she did not think the killing of an Ecuadorean immigrant in December 2008 was driven by bias. ''It was a matter of circumstance,'' said the juror, a 34-year-old white woman who
title: Motive Goes to Heart of Hate Crime Trial as a Jury Begins to Deliberate

author: e-mail: realprop@nytimes.com
body: $6.2 MILLION 280 Johnson Avenue (between Bushwick Place and White Street) Williamsburg, Brooklyn A distributor of raw-cut stone has bought this 32,000-square-foot one-story warehouse with a 21,500-square-foot adjacent lot. Buyer: Babureddy Mareddy Seller: Ben Messing Brokers: Joel Kohn and Avrum Lieber, Kalmon Dolgin Affiliates TRANSACTIONS e-mail:
title: TRANSACTIONS; Recent Sale

body: New York is not Kansas, and yet farms are sprouting up all over town. ''April likes to garden,'' says Ken Friedman, who co-owns the Spotted Pig, the Breslin and the soon-to-be reopened John Dory restaurant with his executive chef, April Bloomfield. Friedman has been busy working the approvals circuit so that he can begin planting the roof of the
title: REMIX; Growth Spurt

body: Gestaltkunstwerke, a new collection of Artware Editions vases by Markus Linnenbrink, above, a German artist known for his glossy epoxy resin paintings and sculptures, grew out of Mr. Linnenbrink's habit of recycling resin in his Bushwick, Brooklyn, studio -- and out of his admiration for used plastic bottles and takeout containers. In a phone
title: CURRENTS | Q&A; Vases That Seem to Say 'Please Touch'

body: EVEN in a season when designers made no secret about reining in prices to appeal to the newly chastened luxury consumer, it is still possible to walk into a store and wonder what exactly they were thinking when a pair of khaki cotton pants -- right there on the hanger, no special packaging or 3G plan or anything -- can cost as much as an iPad.
title: FRONT ROW; Why Does This Pair Of Pants Cost $550?

body: The chances of overhearing a conversation in Vlashki, a variant of Istro-Romanian, are greater in Queens than in the remote mountain villages in Croatia that immigrants now living in New York left years ago. At a Roman Catholic church in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, Mass is said once a month in Garifuna, an Arawakan language that originated
title: Mamuju? Vlashki? Garifuna? In New York, You Hear It All

body: He persuaded his father to bless his departure from their poor village in the mountains of Guatemala by laying out a plan. He would go to New York, work hard and save enough money to buy his family a bigger piece of land. The young man, Hugo Alfredo Tale-Yax, and his father, Juan Pablo Tale, kept in touch, and during the next eight years, Mr.
title: Here to Aid His Family, Left to Die On the Street

body: UPON entering the Red Velvet Lounge on the Lower East Side, one can't help but notice a rather grave Marie Antoinette and Louis XVI watching over everyone -- not exactly the usual faces seen out and about on a Saturday night. The hand-painted ceiling features the distinguished duo's larger-than-life portraits hovering over the crowd in a
title: BOîTE; For the Sweet-Toothed, Cocktails and Cake

body: On the witness stand, Romel Sucuzhañay sat up straight and calmly answered the prosecutor's questions, one after the other. He wore only one expression on his face, a determined scowl that hinted at rage. But then, after a half-hour, he stumbled, over just two words. ''I go to see my brother,'' Mr. Sucuzhañay began, as his head bowed and his
title: Brother of Victim in Baseball-Bat Killing Wrestles With Emotions on the Witness Stand

body: On the benches where the relatives of the defendant sat, heads shook, gazes dropped and a woman cried. On the witness stand, a young man, one of their own, was testifying, saying things that could put the defendant in prison for the rest of his life. The witness, Demetrius Nathaniel, 19, is a cousin of the defendant, Keith Phoenix, who is charged
title: Witnesses Detail Beating of an Immigrant

body: Nothing prepared Veronica Rodriguez for the call she got from a New York City health official last October. A blood sample taken from her 2 1/2-year-old son, Carlos Espinoza, had revealed more than double the level of lead that the federal government considers cause for concern about poisoning. ''I was horrified,'' said Ms. Rodriguez, 26, who lives
title: Lead Threat To Children Proves Hard To Wipe Out

body: A taxi driver testified on Tuesday that he had a clear view when an Ecuadorean immigrant was fatally beaten in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn -- a killing that prosecutors said was motivated by hate. The driver, Davi Almonte, said he was waiting for a traffic light to change when he saw two Hispanic men walking and hugging each other. The next
title: New Hate-Crime Murder Trial, This Time in Brooklyn

body: International LEADING ALLIANCE SEEKS Broader Iraqi Recount A day after an Iraqi court ordered a partial recount of ballots cast in last month's national elections, Ayad Allawi, a former prime minister whose political alliance won the most votes, called for a broader recount of ballots, a move that could deepen the country's instability before the
title: Inside the Times

author: E-mail: dwyer@nytimes.com
body: No matter how many times they played the videos in court on Tuesday, from whatever angle, the story remained the same: A young police officer named Patrick Pogan deliberately shoved a man off his bicycle as he rode through Times Square one night in July 2008. And contrary to the police charges, the videos show that the rider did not ram the
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; In Ex-Officer's Trial, Defense Took a Big Detour, but the Video Didn't

body: He had fired a bullet into his parole officer's upper chest on Thursday evening, the police said, and now Robert Morales was aiming at the officer's face and trying to pull the trigger again to kill the officer, which would probably send him back to prison for good. That, the police said, is what Mr. Morales, 50, told investigators after he was
title: Frustration May Have Led Parolee to Shoot Officer

body: HAVE you seen the Mushroom Man? No? Well, have you looked in the Secret Garden? It's a real place, you know, a half-hidden community garden at the corner of Linden Street and Broadway, in Bushwick, Brooklyn. The Mushroom Man is real, too. His name is Kendall Morrison -- he's 47 years old and semiretired from the publishing business -- and on any
title: Mushrooming? It Sure Is

body: Correction Appended IT helps to be in the right place at the right time, certainly, but the exuberance-of-youth moment that the spacey electro-pop duo MGMT captured around the summer of 2008 was less about serendipity than about having the perfectly tuned attitude, with hooks. Formed by Andrew VanWyngarden and Ben Goldwasser when they were students
title: MUSIC; MGMT's Sophomore Challenges

SAM AMIDON, DOVEMAN (Saturday) A banjoist and singer from Brattleboro, Vt., Sam Amidon plays uncut, earnest folk songs that are both traditional and filled with little surprises, like a sudden, off-key warble or a bit of unexpected percussion. Doveman is the alias of the pianist and composer
title: The Listings

body: ON a bitter Friday night last month about 50 people gathered in LaGuardia Community College's main theater for a workshop presentation of ''The Really Big Once,'' Target Margin Theater's new show exploring the making of Tennessee Williams's 1953 play ''Camino Real.'' The result of an intense collaboration with the director Elia Kazan, ''Camino
title: Some Unsettled Ghosts of Theater Past

body: Mark Goreczny, 23, respects his elders -- all 17,713 of them. They are too frail or disabled to walk to the grocery store, too poor to order takeout, so Mr. Goreczny makes sure they get a free hot meal delivered to their door on weekends and holidays and during emergencies like blizzards, when the city government's weekday meal delivery program
title: ENTRY LEVEL; The Maestro of Weekend Meal Delivery

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: A BEDROOM door: That's what Meghan Galewski and James Gonzalez wanted most. For nearly a year, the couple shared a basement studio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. In an attempt to separate the living area from the sleeping area, they put up a cloth curtain, which of course did nothing to block sounds. Ms. Galewski arose at 5:30 a.m. to get ready for her
title: THE HUNT; Sounds of Silence

body: RABBITS are supposed to be easy to kill. The French dispatch them with a sharp knife to the throat. A farmer in upstate New York swears that a swift smack with the side of the hand works. Others prefer a quick twist of the neck. It didn't seem so easy at the rabbit-killing seminar held in a parking lot behind Roberta's restaurant in the Bushwick
title: Don't Tell the Kids

body: WE were somewhere around Manhattan on the edge of the river when the beers began to take hold. ''There's no sitting on the party bus!'' screamed a bearded man sporting a neck tattoo and glistening in sweat. He was stomping up the aisle of a pulsating bus -- part of a crowd of about 30, drinking free Budweisers and catching a free ride from
title: TALES OF A WINTER'S NIGHT; Tales of a Winter's Night

body: IN the nine years since he came to New York with $500 in his pocket, Martin-Christopher Harper estimates that he has moved at least 40 times. When he lists the neighborhoods he has lived in -- in chronological order -- he sounds like a bartender reciting a long list of microbrews: ''Brooklyn, Chelsea Hotel for a moment, Bronx, Carroll Gardens,
title: Boxed In

body: ''IT'S a lot cheaper to get a new wig than a new wife,'' the art collector Mera Rubell said at the gala on Tuesday for the opening of the Whitney Biennial. Peering out from beneath a spiky platinum Warhol wig, the dark-haired Ms. Rubell gazed up at her husband, Don, a former obstetrician turned art mogul, and added that she had another look for the
title: At the Whitney, Busting Out Quietly

body: Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. AKRON/FAMILY (Wednesday) This trio's scrap-folk is built on the oxymoronic notion of tough fragility, and listening to it feels a little bit like driving a pickup with three good wheels: hold on tight and hope everything sticks together. Expect an entrancing mishmash of found sound, improvisation
title: The Listings: Pop

body: For all the booms and busts he has lived through, Vincent Riso never thought it would come to this: Offering free 42-inch, flat-screen televisions to lure buyers into government-subsidized homes. Historically, such homes have sold quickly. But not at Waters Edge at Arverne, a stretch of 130 town house condominiums Mr. Riso's company, the Briarwood
title: City's Affordable Housing Program Faces Trouble Finding Buyers

body: IT was Valentine's Day at the House of Yes, an old ice warehouse turned event space in Bushwick, Brooklyn: The three-story ''skybox'' was swathed in red satin and velvet, and red aerialists' silks hung from the circus truss that spanned the ceiling. Kae Burke, 23, who runs House of Yes with her high school pal Anya Sapozhnikova, twined her way up
title: Decorating the Night

body: Fighting Hunger Tom Colicchio will be a host, with Natalie Portman, at a benefit on Feb. 21 with food and drinks at Colicchio & Sons, 85 10th Avenue (15th Street), for the Feed Foundation's program called Hungry in America. The program's name is also the title of a documentary film being made by Lori Silverbush, who is Mr. Colicchio's wife, and
title: Calendar

body: Kate Ann Murphy and Charles Franklin Voltz III were married Saturday at St. Anthony Catholic Church in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Donal Burke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Jerry Singleton, the church's pastor, taking part. The bride, 30, is a director of real estate finance in the Manhattan office of the
title: Kate Murphy, Charles Voltz III

body: The Rev. Robert Robinson was sitting at his office computer when he got a call from Linda Freebes, the principal of the parish school. Down the hall, the Rev. Jean-Moise Delva was counseling a couple preparing for marriage when the bride-to-be's cellphone rang. Moments earlier, an earthquake had shaken Haiti. Within minutes, the two priests ran
title: A PARISH TESTED; Quake a Defining Crisis for Two Priests in Queens

body: Philadelphia tore down 21. Chicago leveled 79. Baltimore took down 21 as well, and when 6 of them came down in one day in 1995, it threw a parade. Since the 1990s, public housing high-rise buildings have come tumbling down by the dozens across the country as cities replace them with smaller suburban-style homes that do not carry the stigma of
title: Public Housing Project to Come Tumbling Down

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. ASOBI SEKSU (Friday) What was once called shoegazer rock -- shimmering, multilayered guitars enfolding confessions of longing and ambiguity -- is back in Asobi Seksu, a New York band that wraps its guitars and keyboard around well-made pop melodies and the girlish ache of Yuki Chikudate's
title: The Listings

body: HOW wrong can you go for $2.25? That's the price of a packet of 20 tomato seeds from Baker Creek Heirloom Seeds. The variety I'm considering is called Furry Yellow Hog, and the catalog copy suggests that it has citrus notes and a four o'clock shadow, two traits I have never associated with a tomato. Want to know more? That will not prove easy,
title: IN THE GARDEN; Packets Full of Miracles

body: WHEN Habitat for Humanity New York City consulted an architecture firm on its new site in the Ocean Hill section of Brownsville, Brooklyn, it received a response that switched on a light bulb. The firm, Dattner Architects, said that Habitat could proceed with its plan to build 12 town houses on the trash-strewn vacant lot, but that the site was
title: Making History In a Brooklyn Neighborhood
